titlestmt.titleproper: Norwich (Oscar I.) collection of maps of Africa
Guide to the Oscar I. Norwich Collection of Maps of Africa and Its Islands, 1486 - ca. 1865 NORWICH
titlestmt.author: Processed by Janet Sakai and Peter Whidden

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2017-08-11 16:14:03 -0700.

change.item: Collection transferred to David Rumsey Map Center

did.unittitle: Oscar I. Norwich collection of map of Africa and its islands
did.abstract: The collection contains 316 maps of Africa and its islands collected by Oscar I. Norwich.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content Summary
scopecontent.p: The collection contains 316 maps of Africa and its islands collected by Oscar I. Norwich, and include maps of Southern Africa; sea charts; the Cape of Good Hope; North, East, and West Africa; islands, ports, and town plans.
The majority of the maps are loose items, but a certain number are from rare, published atlases; a few were published in travel books.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Dr. I. Norwich of Johannesburg, South Africa, collected maps, both printed and manuscript, for more than thirty-five years.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Purchased in part with the support of the William R. & Yvonne E. Jacobson Africana Collections Program, 2002.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Image from the Dr. Oscar I. Norwich collection of maps of Africa and its islands, 1486 â€“ ca. 1865 courtesy Stanford Libraries.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: These items are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. If you have questions, please contact the David Rumsey Map Center at rumseymapcenter@stanford.edu.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. All maps have been digitized and are available here: https://searchworks.stanford.edu/view/4719997

did.unittitle: Quarta Affrice Tabula. = Map of Africa. -- Ulm : Leinhart Holle, Ulm (1482 edition); Johann Roger, Ulm (1486 edition)Germanus, Nicolaus

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Atlas based on Ptoleymy's Geographike Hyphegesis. Trapezoidal in projection. Based on Ptolemy's Geographike (about 120-150 AD), printed in Vicenza, Bologna, Florence, Rome and Ulm between 1475 and 1486. These Ptolomaic maps appeared after fall of Constantinople to the Ottoman Turks in 1453.

did.unittitle: Africa a veteribus. -- Venice : Forlani, Paolo

odd.p: Descriptive Notes: There are sea monsters and ships in the Atlantic and Indian Oceans and, to the North of the island of Madagascar, Noah's Ark is depicted, showing the dove returning with an olive branch in its beak.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Not in Norwich Page number:PROBLEM 3/14/02

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Map often referred to as the Prester John map, first issued in Additamentum. Dedicated to biblical David. An Arab dhow appears off the west coast. In the seas, two dolphins and on land four elephants; Map depicts Africa from the Mediterranean to the Mountains of the Moon.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Norwich (2nd ed.), ckey = 3671463 Page number:map 0011, p. 16

did.unittitle: Table d'Afrique. = Map of Africa. -- Paris : Thevet, Andre, 1502-1590 Thevet, Andre, 1502-1590

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: The sea is engraved in horizontal wavy lines which almost overpowers the outline of the continent. The seas contain numerous sailing vessels and sea monsters.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Norwich (2nd ed.), ckey = 3671463 Page number:map 0012, p. 18

did.unittitle: Affricae Tabula Nova. = New map of Africa. -- BaselMunster, Sebastian, 1489-1552

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Based on Abraham Ortelius' maps. The coastline is jagged, and the geography is slightly fictitious. The seas contain two small sailing vessels and one sea monster. The top reads: Africa, Libya, Dozenlandt mit allen koinigreichen ...

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Norwich (2nd ed.), ckey = 3671463 Page number:map 0014, p. 20

did.unittitle: [Depicts Africa from the Mediterranean to The Cape, excluding West Africa] -- Rome : Pigafetta, Filippo, 1533-1604Pigafetta, Filippo, 1533-1604Pigafetta, Filippo, 1533-1604

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Source: Relatione del reame di Congo et delle circonvicine contrade (1591)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Pigafetta's depiction of the origin of the Nile is an important landmark in the historical cartography of the Nile water basin, completely changing the traditional Ptolemaic concept. Dedicated to Antonio Miglioni Vescovo S. Marco.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Norwich (2nd ed.), ckey = 3671463 Page number:map 0016, p. 23

did.unittitle: Africa Tertia Pars Terrae. = Africa the third continent. -- Hanover : Bunting, Heinrich, 1545-1606Bunting, Heinrich, 1545-1606

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Appeared in the first edition of Itinerarum Saccrae Scripturae (1581). This map has an unusual shape, tapering to a narrow angle in the south. The sea is engraved in vertical, wavy lines, with a galleon, a merman and a sea-bird.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Norwich (2nd ed.), ckey = 3671463 Page number:map 0017, p. 25

did.unittitle: Die eigentliche und warhafftige gestalt der Erden und des Meers: Cosmographia Universalis. = The true shape of the world and the oceans. -- Hanover : Bunting, Heinrich, 1545-1606Bunting, Heinrich, 1545-1606

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: "Jerusalem is sited in the centre of the map since it was regarded then as the centre of the world." Portion of America appears, Die Newe Wellt. The sea contains four sea monsters. Top left: 8. Top right: 9.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Norwich (2nd ed.), ckey = 3671463 Page number:map 0018, p. 26

did.unittitle: Africae Vera Forma, et Situs. = The true shape and situation of Africa. -- Antwerp : Jode, Cornelis de, 1568-1600 Jode, Gerard de, 1509-1591 Jode, Gerard de, 1509-1591

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: The seas contain sea monsters and sailing ships. Natives are seen on and around the map.

odd.head: General note

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Source: Atlas sive, Cosmographicae meditationes de fabrica mundi et fabricati figura (1595)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Atlas first published in 1569. Map issued in several editions and in many languages. Includes Latin text on back of map. The cartouche is circular, surrounded by decorative scrolls and two satyrs.

odd.head: General note

did.unittitle: Africa. -- London : Wolfe, John, d. 1601 Pigafetta, Filippo, 1533-1604Pigafetta, Filippo, 1533-1604

odd.p: Descriptive Notes: English edition, copied from the original Italian edition of 1591 (see map NOR 0016). Also appeared in Linschoten's His Discours of Voyages to the East and West Indies (1598). The sea is stippled and contains several ships and sea monsters.

odd.head: General note

did.unittitle: Africa. -- Venice : Porro, Girolamo, 1520-1604Porro, Girolamo, 1520-1604Porro, Girolamo, 1520-1604

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Based on Abraham Ortelius. Various editions of this map appeared between 1596 to 1620. Includes bulge of eastern Brazil down to the mouth of Rio de la Plata.

odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Similar to Abraham Ortelius map of Africa. Includes a scroll-type cartouche, with a lion's head on the lower border. Sea monsters and sailing vessels occupy the stippled sea.

odd.head: General note

odd.p: Source: Rerum et Urbis Amstelodamensium Historia ...

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: The map includes the Middle East, India, and China. Inset illustrates natives in traditional dress.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Norwich (2nd ed.), ckey = 3671463 Page number:map 0028, p. 38

did.unittitle: Africae nova Tabula. = New map of Africa. -- Amsterdam : Hondius, JodocusHondius, Jodocus

odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Border illustrates views of towns and natives in traditional dress. Two Dutch ships are shown in the Atlantic Ocean, with flying fish and sea monsters.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Norwich (2nd ed.), ckey = 3871463 Page number:map 0029, p. 39

did.unittitle: Africae, described, the manners of their Habits, and buildinge: ... -- London : Humble, George, d. 1640 Speed, John, 1552?-1629 Speed, John, 1552?-1629

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: The borders show natives in traditional dress and views of towns.The seas contain flying fish and spouting whales. Elephants, lions, camels, monkeys and ostriches are shown on the mainland. The interior contains rivers, mountains, and lakes, many of which are fictitious. Description of Africa on verso.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Norwich (2nd ed.), ckey = 3871463 Page number:map 0030, p. 40

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Due to its popularity, this map was reprinted many times between 1631 to 1667. Similar features are found on Speed's map (see NOR 0030) and Hondius' map (see NOR 0029).

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Norwich (2nd ed.), ckey = 3871463 Page number:map 0032, p. 42

did.unittitle: Nova descriptio Africae. = New map of Africa. -- Frankfurt : Merian, Matthaeus, 1593-1650Merian, Matthaeus, 1593-1650Merian, Matthaeus, 1593-1650

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Smaller version of Blaeu's map (see NOR 0032), but lacking borders.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Norwich (2nd ed.), ckey = 3671463 Page number:map 0033, p. 42

did.unittitle: Africae nova tabula. = New map of Africa. -- Amsterdam : Jansonium, JoannemHondius, Hendrik, 1597-1651 Hondius, Hendrik, 1597-1651

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Latin text on verso. Re-issue of Jodocus Hondius' map (see NOR 0029), without the borders. Ships, Flying fish, sea monsters and a mermaid riding the waves decorate the seas. "The very full geographical description of Africa is typical of the seventeenth century, and is similar to that of Speed and Bleau."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Norwich (2nd ed.), ckey = 3871463 Page number:map 0034, p. 44

did.unittitle: Africa vetus. = Africa in antiquity ... -- Paris : Sanson, Nicolas, 1600-1667 Sanson, Nicolas, 1600-1667 Sanson, Nicolas, 1600-1667

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: The cartouche is composed of two eagles. The lower part consists of leaves and fruit. Southern part of Africa indicates that the "inhabitants are 'Anthropophagi Aethiopes' or cannibals."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Norwich (2nd ed.), ckey = 3871463 Page number:map 0035, p. 45

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Similar to Chetwind's map (see NOR 0039). The ocean is decorated with ships, flying fish and sea monsters. Elephants, lions, ostriches, and giraffes are illustrated on the mainland. "The River Niger is erroneously mapped and there are many ficticious lakes in Central Africa."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Norwich (2nd ed.), ckey = 3871463 Page number:map 0036, p. 46

odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Re-issued in 1684. "The general shape of Africa is squat because it has been drawn somewhat wider from east to west than usual." Prime meridian through Ferro Island.

odd.head: General note

did.unittitle: A new and most exact map of Africa described by N.I. Vischer and don into English; Enlarged and Corrected according to J. Blaeu and Others, With the Habits of ye people, and ye manner of ye Cheife sitties ye like never before. -- London : Overton, John, 1640-1708? Overton, John, 1640-1708? Overton, John, 1640-1708?

odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Similar to Blaeu's map (see NOR 0030). The sea is decorated with more ships than usual for "maps of this period and the sea monsters are fewer and smaller."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: References: Norwich (2nd ed.), ckey = 3871463 Page number:map 0040, p. 50

odd.p: Descriptive Notes: The continent is misshaped, containing numerous coastal inlets. "All the inhabitants of southern Africa are labeled 'Anthropophagi Aethiopes' or cannibals."

odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Similar to Sanson's map (see NOR 0035). Blome added ships, sea monsters and the dedication to the Right Honourable Charles Howard.

did.unittitle: A Mapp of the Higher and Lower Aethiopia. Comprehending Ye Several Kingdomes c. in Each, to Witt, in the Empire of the Abissines, the Coast of Zanguebar, Abex, and Aian, with the Kingdomes of Nubia, and Biafra c. In the Lower Aethiopia the Kingdome of Congo, Ye Empire of Monomotapa and Monoemugy, Ye Coast and Lands of Cafres and of this Side Cape Negres with the Isles Madagascar c. -- UnknownSanson, Nicholas, 1600-1667

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Source: Hercules siculus sive studium Geographicum (second edition)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Four-sheet folio map. Atlas first issued in 1660. "The map appears upside down, as was the custom with other Italian cartographers."

odd.head: General note

odd.p: Descriptive Notes: First edition of map.Title across top, L'Afrique distinguee en ses principales parties scavoir la Barbarie, le Biledulgerid, L'Egypte, le Saara ou le Desert, le Pays des Negres, la Guinee, La Nubie, L'Abissinie, le Zanguebar; le Congo, le Monomotapa, Les Cafres, Les Isles de Canaries, du Cap-Verd, de S. odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Based on Jaillot's map, (see NOR 0046). Title across top, Africa distinguished in its principal parts viz. Barbary. Biledulgerid, Egypt, Zaara or The Desert, the Country of the Negros, Guinea, Nubia, Abissinea, Zanguebar; Congo, Monomotapa, Caffrares, the Islands of the Canaries, Cape Verd, St. Thomas, Madagascar or St. Lawrence ... Described by Sanson. Corrected and amended by William Berry. Dedicated to Charles II; Prime meridian through Ferro Island.

(Gerard), 1651 or 2-1726. Valck, G. (Gerard), 1651 or 2-1726.

NolinCoronelli, Vincenzo, 1650-1718Coronelli, Vincenzo, 1650-1718Exploration

odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Folio map extends eastward to include the Middle and Far East. Map traces the sea routes of Jesuit Fathers. Inset: Elevation of Table Mountain, Plan of Table Bay, Plans of Siam, Louvo and Batavia; Prime meridian through Ferro Island.

odd.head: General note

did.unittitle: Africa. -- Venice : Coronelli, Vincenzo, 1650-1718Coronelli, Vincenzo, 1650-1718

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Descriptive Notes: Six gores assembled to form one map. One of the most detailed of early maps of Africa. Coronelli stated "besides outlining the Monomotapa and Abyssinia Countries we have been the first to describe correctly the source of Nile River, correcting by many degrees the errors of the Ancients." (E.L. Stevenson, Terrestrial and Celetial Globes, vol. 2, p. 102).
